early he laughed early we were

this is Emily Hagar for the new york
times when he was eight weeks old Owen
Kane was diagnosed with spinal muscular
atrophy type 1 he was only expected to
live two years ready I have 120 and lost
nearly all muscle movement but he lived
his parents taught him how to read do
math even to write okay so this is what
he said to me a couple weeks ago as you
believe me want to walk and then I said
yes I believe that you want to walk and
he said you don't get mad I told him no
I do get mad I'm really mad I'm really
really mad I just don't that's not going
to help us Ellen Goldstein has looked
for help from various technologies for
years but all of them have been
expensive and frustrating failures just
to be quite frank we spend all of this
time and we've spent all of this time
keeping him alive and now we owe him you
know more than that that's my
responsibility and I can't stop trying
to do that maybe I'll MIT one day this
year Owens nurse brought over her
boyfriends ipad so basically when I've
used the ipad with Owen I put his arms
up in the sling because he can move them
a little more and he also has splints
that give his arm and wrist more
stability
let me go there you go ahead I watched
him use it for the first time and he was
interacting the device he was activating
the device he was pushing buttons and
things were happening no that sounds
silly but that was a huge thing to
overcome and everything we've tried like
just getting the device to to activate
with his motion only experts say the
portability the touch screens and the
other built-in features of the newest
mobile devices are game changers for
people with disabilities the ipad is one
of the more superior devices that we
have out there in the market for
patients with disabilities you have to
assist them with their daily activities
traditionally insurance companies don't
cover mobile devices because they are
not considered medical equipment even
with a prescription and even when there
are thousands of dollars cheaper Ellen
worries that the ipad is too pricey for
her family look in with your eyes
though she and her husband both work
they struggled to support their three
kids still she is excited about the
iPads possibilities the principle that
that this device might mean that we can
try a whole bunch of different software
and find something that might work for
him as opposed to being stuck with a
device that cost several thousand
dollars that doesn't work that sits in
his closet and I think that's almost the
most exciting thing the ipad screen is
so sensitive that for the first time
Owen can turn the pages of a book on his
own his mother hopes he can become even
more independent despite his limitations
I think he has the potential
intellectually to be writing essays and
you know doing really sophisticated
things and I don't know physically how
we get him to that place I think that
the more people use these devices you
know the awareness of the public
relating to these lower cost
alternatives improves then I'm hoping
also that the insurance companies that
would have an open mind in terms of
covering these types of devices
recently Owens grandmother bought him an
iPad as a gift and Owen wrote I want to
